channel.title: Stories from nytimes.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best nytimes.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: A 20th-Century Master Scam (1999)
item.description: Before John Myatt was sentenced to prison in February for his part as a forger in perhaps the most ingenious and damaging art con of the 20th century, he lived in a humble cottage on a narrow lane in the idyllic Staffordshire village of Sugnall.

item.title: Moored In A Fragile Paradise
item.description: Hundreds of boaters stuck in the Caribbean have converged on the US Virgin Islands, but there are fears that their safe haven comes at a cost for residents.

item.title: New York Needed Ventilators. So They Developed One In A Month
item.description: The pandemic inspired an innovative project to design and make a low-cost ventilator in weeks, not years.

item.title: Take YouTube's Dangers Seriously
item.description: The website's features can lead people unwittingly to scary places.

item.title: 11 Numbers That Show How The Coronavirus Has Changed New York City
item.description: Unemployment has skyrocketed, but so has the size of the city's volunteer pool and the number of people fostering animals. One month into the shutdown, the city is as complex as it ever was.

item.title: 70 Died At A Nursing Home As Body Bags Piled Up. This Is What Went Wrong
item.description: The sprawling New Jersey nursing home, which was chronically short of staff and protective equipment, quickly fell prey to the coronavirus.

item.title: Protesting For The Right To Catch The Coronavirus
item.description: The reopen America protests are the logical conclusion of a twisted liberty movement.

item.title: A Beloved Bar Owner Was Skeptical About The Virus. Then He Took A Cruise
item.description: Joe Joyce oversaw JJ Bubbles, a welcoming tavern in a conservative corner of Brooklyn, for 43 years until he died of Covid-19.

item.title: The Coronavirus In America: The Year Ahead
item.description: More than 20 experts in public health, medicine and history shared their thoughts on the future. Most believed that once the crisis was over, the nation and its economy would revive quickly. But there would be no escaping a period of intense pain.
item.kicker: 'IF WE UNDERESTIMATE THE VIRUS, IT WILL FIND US'

item.title: They Filed For Unemployment Last Month. They Haven't Seen A Dime
item.description: Crashing websites, disconnected calls and problems with state-issued debit cards are common for the 1.2 million New Yorkers seeking relief.
item.kicker: 'I WOULD BE OK IF I KNEW WHERE MY MONEY WAS'

item.title: A Key GOP Strategy: Blame China. But Trump Goes Off Message
item.description: Republicans increasingly believe that elevating China's culpability for spreading the coronavirus may be the best way to improve their difficult election chances. The president is muddying the message.

item.title: Art Recreation Is The Only Good Instagram Challenge
item.description: Around the world, people are posing as famous portraits with toilet paper, bedsheets, drawn-on unibrows, and did we mention toilet paper?

item.title: Coronavirus Testing Needs To Triple Before The United States Can Reopen, Experts Say
item.description: As some governors consider easing social distancing restrictions, new estimates by researchers at Harvard University suggest that the United States cannot safely reopen unless it conducts more than three times the number of coronavirus tests it is currently administering over the next month.
item.kicker: A MINIMUM OF 152 TESTS PER 100K PEOPLE

item.title: Which Mask Should You Wear?
item.description: Here's a look at some of the types of masks you might encounter, how they work, what to consider when making your own and the level of protection they could provide.

item.title: The Coronavirus Is Mutating. What Does That Mean For A Vaccine?
item.description: Developing a defense against the virus will depend on how it behaves.

item.title: An Army Of Virus Tracers Takes Shape In Massachusetts
item.description: Asian countries have invested heavily in digital contact-tracing, which uses technology to warn people when they have been exposed to the coronavirus. Massachusetts is using an old-fashioned means: people.

item.title: The Epicenter: A Week Inside New York's Public Hospitals, In Photos
item.description: Inside the underfunded, overwhelmed public hospitals that are trying to save New York.

item.title: After Anonymous Tip, 17 Bodies Are Found At Nursing Home Hit By Virus
item.description: There have been 68 recent deaths of residents and nurses from the facility in a small New Jersey town.

item.title: Interactive: How The Coronavirus Is Changing How Americans View One Another
item.description: A new survey shows an increase in feelings of solidarity.

item.title: Lesson From Singapore: Why We May Need To Think Bigger
item.description: A well-run system still led to a lockdown. Maybe the answer to the pandemic is a plan "on a scale that would previously be considered unimaginable."

item.title: The Heartbreaking Last Texts Of A Hospital Worker On The Front Lines
item.description: Madhvi Aya worked long hours in the emergency room of a hospital in Brooklyn that was battered by the coronavirus. Then she caught the virus herself.

item.title: Why The Big Bang Produced Something Rather Than Nothing
item.description: How did matter gain the edge over antimatter in the early universe? Maybe, just maybe, neutrinos.
item.kicker: 'IN A PERFECT UNIVERSE, WE WOULD NOT EXIST'

item.title: How The World's Squarest Fish Gets Around
item.description: The yellow boxfish is much more agile than it looks.

item.title: The Huge Cost Of Waiting To Contain The Pandemic
item.description: As the numbers show, the timing of social distancing can have an enormous impact on death tolls.

item.title: The Food Expiration Dates You Should Actually Follow
item.description: The first thing you should know? The dates, as we know them, have nothing to do with safety.

item.title: This 3-D Simulation Shows Why Social Distancing Is So Important
item.description: If you haven't been keeping your distance to fight the coronavirus, this may persuade you.

item.title: Stay Six Feet Apart, We're Told. But How Far Can Air Carry Coronavirus?
item.description: Most of the big droplets travel a mere six feet. The role of tiny aerosols is the "trillion dollar question."

item.title: California's Coronavirus Shutdowns Set The Tone. What's Its Next Step?
item.description: A state once considered one of the most vulnerable to coronavirus infections has kept deaths comparatively low, and is cautiously looking at next steps.

item.title: I'm An ER Doctor In New York. None Of Us Will Ever Be The Same
item.description: This is what I saw as the COVID-19 pandemic engulfed our hospitals.

item.title: 'This Is Going To Kill Small-Town America'
item.description: Once the coronavirus reached rural Bristol, NH, the effect on the local economy was devastating.

item.title: In Rural Japan, A 370-Year-Old Tradition Falls To One Child
item.description: Every year, students in a mountain village spend months preparing for an elaborate Kabuki performance. An aging society has put their show — and their school — in jeopardy.

item.title: Apollo 13's Astronauts Survived Disaster 50 Years Ago. Could It Happen Again?
item.description: A trip to the moon later this decade should be safer, but it won't be safe.

item.title: Why Biden's Polling Lead Vs. Trump Isn't As Solid As It Looks
item.description: Consider two important measurement differences: battleground states versus other states, and registered voters versus likely voters.

item.title: Bob Iger Thought He Was Leaving On Top. Now, He's Fighting For Disney's Life
item.description: The former CEO thought he was riding into the sunset. Now he's reasserting control and reimagining Disney as a company with fewer employees and more thermometers.

item.title: He Could Have Seen What Was Coming: Behind Trump's Failure On The Virus
item.description: An examination reveals the president was warned about the potential for a pandemic but that internal divisions, lack of planning and his faith in his own instincts led to a halting response.

item.title: 8 Key Exchanges on the Faltering Response to the Coronavirus
item.description: Experts inside and outside the government identified the threat early on and sought to raise alarms even as President Trump was moving slowly. Read some of what they had to say among themselves at critical moments.

item.title: He Could Have Seen What Was Coming: Behind Trump's Failure On The Virus
item.description: An examination reveals the president was warned about the potential for a pandemic but that internal divisions, lack of planning and his faith in his own instincts led to a halting response.

item.title: Life And Death In The 'Hot Zone'
item.description: "If people saw this, they would stay home." What the war against the coronavirus looks like inside two Bronx hospitals.
item.kicker: 'THIS IS NOT A TIME TO DIE'

item.title: Quarantined With A Newborn, Alone
item.description: When I gave birth to my son at the end of January, an unexpected miracle to me at the age of 45, I never could have imagined spending my maternity leave in the middle of a pandemic.

item.title: How The Virus Transformed The Way Americans Spend Their Money
item.description: The coronavirus has profoundly altered daily life in America, ushering in sweeping upheavals to the U.S. economy. Among the most immediate effects of the crisis? Radical changes to how people spend their money.

item.title: The Costly Toll Of Not Shutting Down Spring Break Earlier
item.description: People got sick — and some died — after attending crowded parties and theme parks in Florida as the coronavirus spread.
item.kicker: 'THE GOV'T DIDN'T CANCEL IT, SO IT SHOULD BE FINE'

item.title: Biden And Cuomo: Friends, Allies And Supporting Players No Longer
item.description: A personal friendship has grown into a crucial political alliance as the two men have emerged as pillars of the Democratic Party in a national crisis.
item.kicker: THE GREATEST PUBLIC TRIAL OF THEIR LIVES

item.title: Inside The Strip Clubs Of Instagram
item.description: Going digital may be better for dancers.

item.title: America Will Struggle After Coronavirus. These Charts Show Why
item.description: A portrait of a vulnerable America.

item.title: Jason Isbell On John Prine: 'He Taught Me To Stay Vulnerable'
item.description: If the artist's job is to hold a mirror up to society, John had the cleanest, clearest mirror of anyone.

item.title: The Invasion Of Antarctica Begins With Mussels
item.description: The bivalves — likely transported from Patagonia via ship — are the first nonnative marine species to settle on the White Continent.

item.title: From An Accordion Enthusiast To Comedic Hit-Maker, Weird Al Yankovic's Career Is Illustrious
item.description: The musician and parody hit-maker has spent the better part of the last three-decades creating a legion of fans and admirers over the world. First it was the accordion, then came the jokes and then the songs started.

item.title: Inside New York's Virus Epicenter
item.description: In a city ravaged by an epidemic, few places have been as hard hit as central Queens.

item.title: The Weirdly Enduring Appeal Of Weird Al Yankovic
item.description: National economies collapse; species go extinct; political movements rise and fizzle. But — somehow, for some reason — Weird Al keeps rocking.

item.title: Seven Answers To Questions About The Malaria Drug Trump Keeps Pushing
item.description: Here are the facts on hydroxychloroquine, which the president has promoted despite little evidence that it works against the coronavirus.
